content.description: Climb the right facing flake to the ledge. At ledge shift left and climb the thin crack.
content.location: The last route on the far northern section of rock. To the right of this route is broken up pieces.

content.description:
Climb the dark north-facing inside corner with a large crack. The crack hardly comes into play, though, since it seems simpler and more enjoyable to climb using stemming and holds outside of the crack.

 This is route #2 in both the Swarling/Mayer and Knower books.
content.location: Climb down from the East Bluff Trail on the north end of the Tomahawk area. This inside corner is found just before reaching the low point.

content.description: The route starts at the corner and shift slight to the right. There is a large crack that goes straight up. Follow the crack. The crux of the route is a small bluge. Once you past the bulge the route is much easier.
content.location: This is the left most crack on the face.

content.description: This is the far right crack on the northern end of the farthest north rocks of Tomahawk rocks.
content.protection: There is plenty of places to put protection.
content.location: As you come down to Tomahawk from the north end look to the left. It is the nice crack to the left.

content.description: Start off the block. Climb the thin,awkward, jagged seam just a few feet right of Brave .
content.location: On the south-facing wall protected by a large cedar tree. Teepee is between Brave and Axeman.

content.description: Thin side-pulls to a ledge, then blocky moves to the top.
content.location: Thin crack to the left of "Puzzlement" (Tomahawk Rocks #10).

content.description:
That puzzling size that is a bit wide for off-width, but too narrow to chimney. 

  As is typical for our quartzite, you might use some off-width holds (arm bars, heel-and-toes), but you don't really have to make any off-width moves - there is always an edge someplace, if you can figure out how to use it!
content.location: The offwidth/squeeze chimney at the right hand end (south end) of the formation.

content.description:
If you were puzzled by Puzzlement to the left, you may be perplexed by this one. Difficult climbing at the bottom makes you wonder about the 5.9 rating, especially just above the overhang. But it leads to some interesting climbing on thin holds on the upper half.The guidebooks don't say anything about whether the left or right corners are off. Although it seems like cheating using either corner, it still is no cake-walk. 

 This is an unnamed 5.9 route in the guidebooks.
content.location: Located near the south end of the Tomahawk buttress (not counting the separate small wall 80 ft south of here.) It is the face with a couple shallow roofs between the off-width crack (Puzzlement) and the sharp corner on the right (Mohawk). An access route from the East Bluff trail can be found just south of the sharp corner.

content.description: Typical quartzite face climbing.  Goes at 5.6-5.8 depending on how disciplined you are about not using the rocks behind you at the start.
content.location: Around the corner to the right of Puzzlement, on the SE facet of the 3rd Tomahawk buttress.

content.description: Start on the smoothest face on this wall between the right corner and the easier cracks and broken rocks to the left. When you reach the wide ledge just below the summit rocks, decide whether to bail out to the left, or climb straight up the lake-facing summit blocks to the top.
content.protection: It's a tricky toprope setup - either climb to the top of the rock, or thow your anchor over the top, or set the anchor lower where it is easier to reach. The top rock of The McCord can be seen from the East Bluff trail. It's about 50 ft north of and a bit farther from the trail than the Tomahawk Rock.
content.location: Find the separate small wall about half-way between the Tomahawk wall proper and the Tomahawk Rock. Either angle your way down and north from the East Bluff trail near Tomahawk Rock, or angle your way up and south from the bottom of the small wall. The start of the McCord is guarded by a decent sized birch tree and a very small pine.

content.description: This route is about 5 feet to the right of Tomahawk crack. The start is about the same as Tomahawk then it moves farther right. The route accends the easy broken terrain.
content.location: To the right of Tomahawk crack

content.description: Face with right-facing hanging dihedral near the right side of the wall
content.location: On the small wall located about 80 feet south of Tomahawk's main wall and just north off the Tomahawk Rock.

content.description: This is a nice little 5.9 route. It is mainly slab climbing on small holds.(Name suggested by Pete Cleveland.)
content.protection: I tagged it as top rope.
content.location: This route is to the right of Jay's Jaunt. It is on the slab face. It is the only route that looks like a 5.9 slab climb.

content.description:
Step up on the flat rock and climb up the flakey right side of the diamond-shaped rock to the ledge about half-way up. From the ledge, climb over the middle of the roof using the nice hand jam crack.

 Not listed in the guidebooks.
content.location: On the lake-facing wall near the northern end of Tomahawk area, look for the somewhat diamond-shaped rock that slightly juts out of the wall about 10 ft up, and is split by a vertical crack.

content.description: Looks like there should be more to work with than there is.  Start just right of the crack - the wall is just barely overhanging.  Move left and up into the crack.  Where the "crack" widens (but seams out), move further left and continue fighting your way up.
content.protection: Finger-sized and smaller.  You will have to decide between pro or holds.
content.location: Crack just right of the second buttress' prow.

content.description: Climb up the sharp lichen-covered nose of the arete (it's OK to favor one side or the other, rather than straight over the tip). When the angle of the arete eases, step across the V trough and climb the opposite side using a slanting sharp crack to the right corner. Finish by pulling the overhang at the top.
content.location: Find the separate small wall about half-way between the Tomahawk wall proper and the Tomahawk Rock. An access route from the East Bluff trail can be found on either the north or south side of this wall, but the north seems more well traveled. At the low point of this small wall, look for the nose on the sharp corner on the right side.

content.description:
Climb the slab and face on thin holds. Start right of an inside corner and left of an outside corner and go straight up to top. Easier slab climbing at the bottom becomes harder as the angle steepens and the holds get thinner.

 Using the outside corner on the right makes it a 5.7.

 This is an unnamed 5.10a in both the Swartling/Mayer and Knower books.
content.location: Approaching from the north, pass Tomahawk Crack and the other routes at the low point of Tomahawk Rocks, then scramble up a bit past some junky rock. You'll then see a nice clean lake-facing piece of rock with a shallow roof near the top.

content.description: Perfect hand jams.  The final jam may be a bit dirty.
content.location: On the second Tomahawk buttress, the recessed crack to the right of "Brave" and "Teepee".

content.description: The most shaded, most obscure of the three North End areas.
